AAt a meeting between the Political Resident (Colonel Fowle), the Adviser to the Bahrain G-ovemment (Mr.Belgrave) and the Political Agent,Bahrain,(Colonel Loch),the question of Mr. Belgrave working on the Bahrain Court was discussed. It was considered that he had far too much work to do to justify his spending long hours on the Bahrain Court. It was further considerea that it was not altogether desirable that he should sit on the Court permanently,though this may have been justified when the post of Adviser was first created. It is not possible for him to cease his duties on the Court at once as it might be regarded as a sign of disagreement between him and Shaikh Salman, who is at present disgruntled over tne 1 slaughter-house 1 question and also regards himself as underpaid for the work which he does. 2. It was decided that Mr.Belgrave should gradually go less and less to the Court and that at the end of his leave he should definitely leave the Court work in the hands of Shaikh Salman. It was thought that it might be possible to get over the slaughterhouse fees difficulty by giving Shaikh Salman a definitely higher rate of pay and putting him in charge of the Court,it being understood that he would relinquish his claims to the slaughter-housb fees. This will need discussion in detail between the Political Agent and the Adviser. 3. It was,however,considered undesirable that Mr.Belgrave should disassociate himself from the Pearling Court side of tne Court oecause the Salafiyah Court to wnich pearling cases were reierrea was composed of Nakhudahs who would doubtless revert to their old ways and the oppression of the divers if they were not strictly supervised. In view of the interest of the outside world in the state of pearl divers (which is regarded as connected with slavery) it was decided that Mr.Belgrave should continue to sit when pearling cases were taken up.© 2 4. The Political Agent thought that it would be advisable to have some machinery whereby Mr.Belgrave could sit on the Court if any cases were to come up of financial or political import ance. physicalDescription.extent: File papers are arranged chronologically. There are file notes (folios 27 and 28).

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 29; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-21; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence about Shaikh Salman bin Hamad al Khalifah, mainly from the 1930s. The main topic is the work of Shaikh Salman in the Bahrain Court and the payment of a small extra subsidy when Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, Adviser to the Government, was on leave in England.The main correspondents are Gordon Percy Loch, Political Agent at Bahrain; Shaikh Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifah, Ruler of Bahrain; Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, Adviser to the Bahrain Government;
